author: viperstakepool
title: Stake Pool Keys in libcardano
description: The Cardano ecosystem has a new C++ library that exposes Cardano to one of the largest developer communities; however, the library does not yet provide stake pool cryptographic functionalities.

f6_assessments.q0: Yes, the proposers suggest to add Stake Pool Key Management functionalities to a C++ Library that they have built previously.  They suggest it will bring additional developers into the Cardano ecosystem and give existing C++ developers example code from which to start their own projects. As a developer, I think diversity in implementations is always good. So it brings new developers and enhances the experience of existing developers. The project scales well as it will be released as open-source on GitHub, and the proposers will come back for additional funding if the community finds it valuable.
f6_assessments.q1: Yes, the project will be delivered by 2 individuals: Dylan and Willie. Their short CVs are provided, but no social media links.  It would have been nice to see some social media links so their track record could be verified. When searching for Dylan it shows his Linkedin page that corroborates his experience. The deliverable is split into four parts and each one relates to the generation of different types of keys for the stake pool. As a stake pool operator myself, I recognize the types of keys and can confirm that they are required. The budget is outlined clearly and broken into sections.  Each section has an hourly expenditure at cost of $40 per hour.  Given the proposers’ experience and that they have built tools on Cardano before, this is a very competitive hourly rate and much below the average of the 30+ proposals I have reviewed so far. The total budget is $12,000. The proposed timeline is to finish in Q1 next year, which is reasonable considering it would take them 160 hours to complete. The risk highlighted is that the team might need to do some learning about the detail of how Cardano nodes encryption works if they encounter difficulties with the implementation. I think this is a small risk and a meaningful mitigation strategy as everyone at some point finds that they need to learn something new when delivering a project.  Overall, the timeline, the architecture, the language, and the technical details of the implementation are adequately described. I think the team has a very good chance to deliver this project on time and on budget
f6_assessments.q2: Yes, The progress on the project will be measured by the number of commits per month on the public GitHub repo and a successful delivery will be a series of tests published as open-source on GitHub and available for others to use at the end of the project. Given that the tool is being built for the community I would have liked to see some measures of community adoption.  The proposers are active in the community, and I have no doubt that the community would be able to audit them based on the information provided in this proposal and by reaching out on Github and other social media channels.

f6_assessments.q0: The "Stake Pool Keys in libcardano" proposal addresses the Developer Ecosystem Challenge by adding the open-source C++ library to provide stake pool cryptographic functionalities. The proposal also fits the strategic of Cardano to have more open-source projects within the ecosystem. The added library will round up more developers from the C++ community and provide them with samples/templates and extend knowledge base. Rightly, the proposer will have to go through project documentation and example code in the IOHK repositories and the risk that the team would have to re-learn to extend this functionality. With this proposal, it will open the gate for C++ developers to have a go at Cardano and hence, satisfies the goal of this challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: A very clear roadmap from the proposer. Also I appreciate the fact that he is extremely conservative with the estimate pay range of $40/hour. He values the Catalyst funding and requests a very reasonable budget of $12800. The team is comprised of 2 highly capable individuals with strong background and they are funded proposers who complete the Catalyst projects successfully. Note to the team, please provide linkedin or bio profile next time. I rank their proposal 5 as I am very confident that they will hit their targets with their conservative budget, strong team and clear roadmap. It was not the first time I come across their stake pool names "Viper stakepool" and I believe that their team can make this project a success.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal is very organized with the well chosen metrics/KPIs which are good indicators of evaluating success. Their measures for success are git commits (5 per month) and unit tests (at least once per month) on stake pool VRF Keys (signature and verification), the stake pool KES keys and the stake pool cold keys serialized to CBOR. The community can track project progress and updates on gitlab (libcardano) making this project auditability very high.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal has identified the shortcoming of the Cardano open-source library for C++ developers - the lack of cryptographic functionalities. Due to this, this proposal sets out to solve that problem by proposing to add 4 stake pool keys, as specified in the proposal. Although the intention of the proposal to update cryptographic functionalities to the Cardano C++ library is clear, the proposer should give some explanation why the proposer chooses to add these 4 stake pool keys. The proposer could mention their strengths and compatibility to the Cardano library, or their commonality (something most C++ developers are familiar with and can utilize at ease). It is true that the proposal is well-aligned with the challenge and the impacts of this proposal are also clearly presented. More handy functionalities in the Cardano open-source library are encouraging for C++ developers and can attract more of them to onboard. In turn, the Cardan ecosystem will benefit from the contribution that these developers could bring. These functionalities could be an educational tool that widen the knowledge of the Cardano developer community. Regarding the main risk, the proposer mentions the “learning opportunity” from “some tasks”, which could have been more specific for better comprehension. It can be assumed that documentation and example code in the IOHK repositories have helped them to mitigate the problems arising from those tasks.
f6_assessments.q1: A specific timeline is provided and divided into 2 stages in Q4/2022 and Q1/2023. Clear activities are included in these 2 stages. The budget breakdown is according to the hourly rate of 40usd/hour which is a conservative estimation. The budget breakdown allows us to see that 2 developers will be in charge of implementing these stake pool keys and the working horse will be 160 hours in total, which is good for transparency. The team consists of these two developers whose expertise is Computer Engineering and Computer Science, which is suitable for this proposal. They also have participated in the Catalyst funding project and successfully delivered the products. The proposal will need more funding in a later round if it achieves certain success. The proposer should add a brief explanation for what will the funding in the next rounds be used for (sub-projects, technicality, resources, update more functionality,...).
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer acknowledges the measurability of 5 git commits a month is not the most optimal method so they provide additional unit tests. However, it is still unclear how these unit tests will represent a good indicator for progress tracking. The proposer should elaborate more on this as the technical aspects are not very clearly presented and explained. Moreover, the proposer could have beta testing for C++ developers to try the efficiency of these functionality and collect their feedback. The key metrics are quite clear and reasonable. SDG goal given is saving carbon footprints thanks to the energy-efficient C++ programming.

solution:
We propose to add the following capabilities to libcardano (the open-source Cardano C++ library):

Stake pool VRF keys (including signature and verification)
Stake pool KES keys
Stake pool cold keys
experience: The Viper Staking Team has operated a stake pool on the Cardano blockchain since the incentivized testnet (2019). The team has recently developed the open-source C++ library, libcardano which already provides functionality for working with Cardano wallets.
